p.content: Adverbs express four basic types of information: time, location, manner, and reason or purpose. Adverbial indefinites are also discussed. Interrogative adverbs are covered in
Temporal adverbs include the English words:
, and
The temporal adverbs in
are:
Many languages allow degree words to modify adverbs. Example English positive temporal adverbial phrases including degree word modifiers are:
and
In
, temporal adverbs are not modified or intensified.
In
, temporal adverbs may be modified by degree words which occur

after or on both sides of
on either side or on both sides of
the temporal adverb and may also occur ___

p.content: The degree words which can modify the temporal adverbs in
are shown here:
Examples of temporal adverbs with degree words modifying them are:
affixes or clitics that attach to the temporal adverb to intensify it. The degree affixes or clitics which can modify temporal adverbs are:
Examples of temporal adverbs with a degree affix or clitic attached are:

text.content: Temporal adverbs may also use reduplication to

p.content: intensify the meaning of the temporal adverb. Examples of the temporal adverbs with reduplication modifying or intensifying them are:
modified or intensified by ___
. Examples of temporal adverbs which are modified or intensified in this way are:
The time element of a sentence is often expressed by nouns. Some examples are:
These temporal nouns can also be modified, as shown in these temporal nominal phrases:

The time element of a sentence can also be expressed by other types of words or phrases, such as adpositional phrases and adverbial clauses. These phrases occur in the same positions as the temporal adverbs, normally either initially or finally in the clause. See section
for the structure of nominal phrases and section
for information on adpositional phrases. See also section
for examples of temporal adverbial clauses.
The time element of a sentence can also be expressed by other types of words or phrases, such as prepositional phrases
, and adverbial clauses
. These phrases occur in the same positions as the temporal adverbs, normally either initially or finally in the clause. See section
for the structure of nominal phrases and section
for information on adpositional phrases. See also section
for examples of temporal adverbial clauses.
Locative adverbs include the English words:
The roots of the locative adverbs in
are shown here Each one may surface with the apropriate classifier attached.
The locative adverbs in
are shown here:
In
the forms of these locative adverbs are

case.caseText: completely distinct from the demonstrative pronouns.
identical to the demonstrative pronouns, though they are used in different positions in the sentence.
identical to the demonstrative pronouns, but others are distinct.
related to the demonstrative pronouns. An affix is added to a demonstrative to form a locative adverb.
related to the demonstrative pronouns. An affix is added to a locative adverb to form a demonstrative.
related to the demonstrative pronouns in this way:

p.content: See section
for information on the demonstrative pronouns.
Many languages allow degree words to modify adverbs. In English, locative adverbs can be modified by
and
, as in:
and
Locative adverbs are not modified or intensified in.
In
, locative adverbs may be modified by degree words which occur

p.content: intensify the meaning of the locative adverb. Examples of the locative adverbs with reduplication modifying or intensifying them are:
modified or intensified by ___
. Examples of locative adverbs which are modified or intensified in this way are:

Location is often expressed by an adpositional phrase or just a nominal phrase, consisting of a proper name or a description of the place. Locative expressions may normally occur either initially or finally in the clause, or as complements to motion verbs. See section
for examples with motion verbs.
Location is often expressed by a prepositional phrase, such as:

. Many languages allow just a nominal phrase, consisting of a proper name or a description of the place. Locative expressions may normally occur either initially or finally in the clause, or as complements to motion verbs. See section
for examples with motion verbs.
Manner adverbs directly modify the verb and may be independent words or attached to the verb.
Manner adverbs directly modify the verb and usually end in
in English. Some languages do not have independent words, but rather use verbal affixes to express manner.
Manner adverbs in
are all written as independent words. Examples are:
Some of the manner adverbs in
are written as independent words, but some attach to the verb. The affix forms are shown with a hyphen in the following table.
Manner adverbs in
are all written as affixes on the verb. These affixes are:
Manner adverbs can usually be modified by degree words. In English, manner adverbs can be modified by
and
, as in:
and
Manner adverbs are not modified or intensified in.
Manner adverbs which are written as independent words are not modified or intensified in.
In
, the manner adverbs
may be modified by degree words which occur

p.content: Manner adverbs do not seem to have clear counterparts in other phrase types, except possibly some comparatives. See section
for examples.
Manner adverbs do not seem to have clear counterparts in other phrase types, except possibly some comparatives, such as
. Comparatives are dealt with in section
Reason or purpose may be expressed by a single adverb or by an adverbial clause or adpositional phrase.
Reason or purpose adverbs include
and
. Reason or purpose adverbs do not allow modifiers in English. Reason or purpose can also be expressed by an adverbial clause beginning with
or
or
. These adverbial phrases or clauses occur either initially or finally in the sentence. The structure of the adverbial clauses will be addressed in section
Reason or purpose adverbs which either stand alone or begin an adverbial clause expressing reason or purpose in
are:
Reason or purpose can also be expressed by a prepositional phrase in English, such as
or
. Such phrases are described in section
phrases in
which express reason or purpose are:

headerRow.headerCol: Other expressions of reason or purpose

p.content: Full sentence examples including adverbs or adverbial clauses or
phrases expressing reason or purpose are:
See section
for more information on
phrases and section
for adverbial clauses expressing reason or purpose.
There are two basic sets of indefinite adverbs, though not all languages merge them into a single word: those consisting of a quantifier and a generic noun, such as
and those built from an interrogative word and an indefinite, such as
and

Adverbial indefinites are used to refer to a nonspecific time or location. They normally consist of either a quantifier and a generic noun or an interrogative word and an indefinite word, and they may not be merged into a single word.
Beginning with the first type which includes a quantifier and a generic noun, in
the temporal indefinites

text.content: are expressed by a quantifier and a generic noun merged into a single word.
are sometimes expressed by a quantifier and a generic noun merged into a single word, but some remain as a phrase.
are sometimes expressed by a quantifier and a generic noun merged into a single word, but some are expressed by ___
are expressed by a quantifier and a generic noun which do not merge into a single word, but remain as a phrase.
are sometimes expressed by a quantifier and a generic noun which do not merge into a single word, but remain as a phrase, and some are expressed by ___
are sometimes expressed by a quantifier and a generic noun merged into a single word, but some remain as a phrase, and some are expressed by ___
